docs.lead_paragraph: After several years of litigation, the American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to offer cash settlements to about 36,000 women who contended that they had not been adequately warned about the possible side effects of the company's Norplant contraceptive. Under the terms of the settlement, American Home Products is expected to pay out at least $50 million, said Turner W. Branch, one of the lead lawyers for the plaintiffs. Women who choose to settle will receive $1,500 each, far from the amount lawyers had hoped for.

headline.main: Maker of Norplant Offers a Settlement In Suit Over Effects

docs.abstract: American Home Products Corp, after several years of litigation, agrees to offer cash settlements to about 36,000 women who contend that they had not been adequately warned about possible side effects of company's Norplant contraceptive; Turner W Branch, one of lead lawyers for plaintiffs, says that under terms of settlement, American Home Products is expected to pay out at least $50 million; says women who choose to settle will receive $1,500 each (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning a pregnant Bronx woman's water broke. She got in her car and began driving to North Central Bronx Hospital, heading north on the Major Deegan Expressway. There was just one problem: The flooding and the traffic were so bad the woman became trapped in her car. It was to be the ninth child for the 44-year-old woman, whose name was not disclosed. She had a medical history that could have put her or her child at risk, which meant there was little time to spare. The northbound lanes were so impassable, even emergency vehicles were unable to reach her.

headline.main: Stranded on the Deegan With a Baby Who Was Ready to Escape the Womb

docs.abstract: Pregnant Bronx woman going into labor is trapped on Major Deegan Expressway during flooding-related traffic jam, but is rescued by Emergency Medical Service and taken to North Central Bronx Hospital (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An unwanted birth can have harmful emotional effects not only on the mother and her child but on other children in the family as well, researchers at the University of Michigan have found. And their study says the damage can last well into adulthood. The study, published in the September issue of the Journal of Health and Social Behavior, analyzed two sets of data.
docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Michigan find that unwanted birth can have harmful emotional effects not only on mother and her child, but on other children in family as well (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Wishing for a girl is one thing, but being obsessed is another. Yet I do sympathize. When I was pregnant with my second child (and I knew it would be my last), I learned during the ultrasound that I was going to have another boy. Disappointed, I went home, allowed myself a few tears and then gave thanks that by all accounts my child was healthy. Not all parents receive such good news. Barbara Reitz Hampton, N.J.
docs.abstract: Barbara Reitz letter on Lisa Belkin's July 25 article on advances in sex preselection recalls her own reaction to learning that her second child would be boy (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lisa Belkin's article (July 25) on medical advances in sex preselection was astute and gripping. I was less concerned by ethical issues than by the women interviewed, who were in such a collective froth to conceive babies with the right chromosomes. (Interestingly, the husbands were indifferent on the matter.) ''It was like I was robbed of my little girlyhood,'' said one woman. Nell Beram Cambridge, Mass.
docs.abstract: Nell Beram letter expresses concern over women interviewed in Lisa Belkin's July 25 article on medical advances in sex preselection (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: British Airways seems to have a knack for hiring women flight attendants who take timing seriously. In May at the Genoa, Italy, airport, one reportedly ran a lap around a plane wearing, er, much less than the regulation uniform after she lost a bet with a pilot over when their flight would land.
docs.abstract: British Airways reports that more than 600 flight attendants, about third higher than normal, have been assigned to ground duties because they are pregnant and due around end of year (S)
